docs.title: Setting up a dev container for Rust
docs.text:
• Primary author: Bamlak Tesfaye
  • Reviewer: Yunseok Hwang

This tutorial will guide you through setting up a Dev Container for Rust development in VSCode. We’ll cover everything from creating a blank directory to writing, compiling, and running a simple "Hello COMP423" Rust program.

docs.title: Part 1: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before you begin, make sure you have the following:

  • Git installed: Install Git if you don’t already have it.

  • A GitHub account: If you don’t have one yet, sign up at GitHub.

  • VSCode: Download and install VSCode.

  • Docker: Install Docker Desktop for container management.
  • Dev Containers Extension: Install the Dev Containers extension in VSCode.

docs.title: Step 1. Start with a Blank Directory
docs.text:
1. Create a new directory for your project: 
    mkdir rust-dev-container
cd rust-dev-container

Note

It's important to name your directories descriptive like the example above

  1. Initialize a Git repository: 
    git init
  2. Create a README file:
echo "# Running Rust in a Dev Container" > README.md
git add README.md
git commit -m "Initial commit with README"

docs.title: Step 2. Create a Remote Repository on GitHub
docs.text:
1. Log in to your GitHub account and navigate to the Create a New Repository page.
  2. Fill in the details as follows:
  3. Repository Name: rust-dev-container
  4. Description: "A Rust project running in a Dev Container with VS Code."
  5. Visibility: Public
  6. Do not initialize the repository with a README, .gitignore, or license.
  7. Click Create Repository.

docs.title: Step 3. Link Your Local Repository to GitHub
docs.text:
1. Add the GitHub repository as a remote:

    git remote add origin https://github.com/<your-username>/rust-dev-container.git
    Replace <your-username> with your GitHub username.

docs.title: Step 2: Check and Rename Branch, Push Commits
docs.text:
1. Check your default branch name with the subcommand git branch. If it's not main, rename it to main with the following command:

git branch -M main
Old versions of git choose the name master for the primary branch, but these days main is the standard primary branch name.

  1. Push your local commits to the GitHub repository: 
    git push --set-upstream origin main

Explaining --set-upstream

The command git push --set-upstream origin main pushes your local main branch to the remote repository named origin. The --set-upstream flag links your local branch to the remote one, so in the future, you can just use git push or git pull without needing to specify the branch name.

docs.title: Part 2. Setting Up the Development Environment
Step 1. Add Development Container Configuration
docs.text:
1. In VS Code, open the rust-dev-container directory. You can do this via: File > Open Folder.

  2. Install the Dev Containers extension for VS Code.

  3. Create a .devcontainer directory in the root of your project with the following file inside of this "hidden" configuration directory:

.devcontainer/devcontainer.json

The devcontainer.json file defines the configuration for your development environment. Here, we're specifying the following:

  • name: A descriptive name for your dev container.
  • image: The Docker image to use, in this case, the latest version of a Python environment. Microsoft maintains a collection of base images for many programming language environments, but you can also create your own!
  • customizations: Adds useful configurations to VS Code, like installing the Python extension. When you search for VSCode extensions on the marketplace, you will find the string identifier of each extension in its sidebar. Adding extensions here ensures other developers on your project have them installed in their dev containers automatically.
  • postCreateCommand: A command to run after the container is created. In our case, it will use pip to install the dependencies listed in requirements.txt.

docs.title: Step 2: Configure the Dev Container
docs.text:
1. Inside the .devcontainer folder, create a devcontainer.json file with the following content: 

    {
"name": "Rust Tutorial",
"image": "mcr.microsoft.com/devcontainers/rust:latest",
"customizations": {
    "vscode": {
        "settings": {},
        "extensions": ["rust-lang.rust-analyzer"]
    }
},
"postCreateCommand": ""
}

    Explanation:

    • image: Uses the official Rust Dev Container base image from Microsoft.

    • customizations.vscode.extensions: Installs the official rust-analyzer extension for better coding experience.

    • postCreateCommand: Verifies the installation by showing the installed version of rustc.

docs.title: Step 3: Reopen the Project in a VSCode Dev Container
docs.text:
Reopen the project in the container by pressing Ctrl+Shift+P (or Cmd+Shift+P on Mac), typing "Dev Containers: Reopen in Container," and selecting the option. This may take a few minutes while the image is downloaded and the requirements are installed.

Once your dev container setup completes, close the current terminal tab (trash can), open a new terminal pane within VSCode, and try running:

rustc --version

Note

The rustc --version command checks the version of the Rust compiler installed on your system.

docs.title: Part 3: Create and Initialize a Rust Project
docs.text:
1. Open your directory in VSCode: 
    git remote add origin https://github.com/<your-username>/rust-dev-container.git

  2. Reopen the folder in the Dev Container by clicking Reopen in Container in the bottom-right corner of VSCode.

  3. Use cargo to create a new binary project without initializing a Git repository: 

    cargo new hello_comp423 --vcs none
    This creates a new Rust project in a folder named hello_comp423.

  4. Navigate to the project directory: 

    cd hello_comp423

docs.title: 2. Write the "Hello COMP423" Program
docs.text:
1. Open the main.rs file located in src/: 
    code src/main.rs
  2. Replace the contents with: 
    fn main() {
    println!("Hello COMP423");
}

docs.title: 3. Build and Run the Program
docs.text:
1. Build the Project: 

    cargo build
    This compiles your Rust program. The compiled binary can be found in the target/debug directory.

    • Discussion: This is similar to the gcc command in COMP211, where you manually compile your code.

  2. Run the Compiled Binary: 

    ./target/debug/hello_comp423
    You’ll see the following output: 
    Hello COMP423

  3. Use the cargo run Command: Instead of building and running separately, you can use: 

    cargo run

    • Difference: The cargo run command combines the build and run steps into one.

docs.title: 6. Verify the Rust Version
docs.text:
To confirm you’re using a recent version of Rust, run: 

rustc --version

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: Great job you've just finished setting up your developement environment and you've written 'Hello COMP423' program in Rust. These are vital skills and hats off to you for taking that first step to tackle all types of projects, whether professional or open-source. Nice!!
